history.content:
Courses in the Sociology department with Prof. Linus Huang are nice – his courses are all structured such that there are just 2 take-home midterms (each of which are worth 40% and you have a week to do), and a 20% in-person multiple choice final. The grading is pretty lenient and very transparent.

I took one of his courses last semester and will be taking one this semester too (I believe this semester he's teaching Sociology 110, the sociology of organizations).

-----

ENGIN 185 is a new class that's pretty good. It's co-taught by the Dean (Professor Tsu-Jae), it's not too much work, and it's pretty fun. It satisfies both the upper division HSS and Ethics requirement for EECS majors, so that's two check marks there.

Courses in the Sociology department with Prof. Linus Huang are nice – his courses are all structured such that there are just 2 take-home midterms (each of which are worth 40% and you have a week to do), and a 20% in-person multiple choice final. The grading is pretty lenient and very transparent.

I took one of his courses last semester and will be taking one this semester too (I believe this semester he's teaching Sociology 110, the sociology of organizations).

children.subject:
If Niek Veldhuis is teaching Near Eastern Studies 105A, I would definitely recommend. Fairly little homework assigned, which all follows the pattern of 'what did you think of the text', the midterm took less than an hour, and we had a take home collaborative final. He's really personable and he makes the subject matter (which for the most part is lore) interesting. The hardest part about the class is the 15 min presentation, but it can literally be about anything having to do with the text read in class, and many of my class didn't even hit the 15 minute mark.

Otherwise, good luck finding a humanities class without a paper due.

I recommend the History 124 series if you're interested in American history. Two essays, an in class midterm, and a final. Readings are assigned but it's very little time commitment (the profs don't recommend thoroughly reading them, just skimming and picking out main ideas.)

Could someone elaborate on the workload for Engin 185: the Art of STEM Communications?

What is the grading scheme? Is there a final project?

history.content: I am currently looking for an easy upper div humanities course to take with minimal time commitment. Does anyone have any suggestions for one? Preferably no exams and/or little to no homework?
history.subject: Upper div humanities
